attributes.title: Effectiveness of N95 Respirators versus Surgical Masks for Preventing Acute Respiratory Infection among Healthcare Workers: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

summary.value: The outbreak of the 2019-nCoV have triggered global discussion again on the controversial recommendations about the effectiveness of N95 filtering facepiece respirators (N95 respirators) versus surgical masks in preventing acute respiratory infection. As the coronavirus epidemic gradually spread between nations and regions, the panic that led to a shortage of face masks has driven another socioeconomical issue. Acute respiratory infections, including COVID-19, are primarily transmitted by contact and droplet routes; consequently, protection of the respiratory tract became an important issue. Former guideline published by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) suggests the superiority of N95 respirators over surgical masks for preventing acute respiratory infections. Meanwhile, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), observational studies, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses comparing N95 respirators and surgical masks have not shown conclusive results. With a recently published RCT indicating no significant difference in the incidence of laboratory-confirmed influenza between N95 respirators and surgical masks, there may be new evidence in the debate. Thus, this systemic review and meta-analysis of RCTs aimed to clarify the effectiveness of N95 respirators versus surgical masks in preventing acute respiratory infection.

name.value: The Psychology of Sitting Behaviour (PhD Project) - Environmental design and sitting behaviour at work

other.value:
Individual office characteristics. 
As secondary analysis, we additionaly explore the role of each individual office design characteristic. For each characteristic, we fit two shared frailty cox models, and summarise HRs and confidence intervals for each predictor in a dot-whisker diagram to interpret the results. We will use treatment constrasts for categorical predictors.

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ office-characteristic + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ office-characteristic + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

Work characteristics. 
As robustness analyses, we explore whether the associations that find in our main analyses (e.g., between workplace spatial layout and the hazard to stand up when sitting) can alternatively be explained from the assessed work characterstics. 

Workplace habits. 
As additional secondary analysis, we explore the role of workplace habits in sitting patterns at work. For each workplace habit predictor, we will fit two shared frailty cox models, and summarise HRs and confidence intervals for each predictor in a dot-whisked diagram to interpret the results. We use treatment constrasts for categorical predictors. 

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ workplace-habit-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ workplace-habit-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

Temporal dynamics and physical fitness.
For the secondary aim of the present research, i.e. to replicate and validate findings from Ten Broeke and colleagues (manuscript in preparation) regarding the baseline temporal dynamics of the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing, and associations with time of the day, activity in last 5 hours, age, BMI, and leisure time activity level, we will conduct the analysis plan of the original study (see ‘linked registrations’ for the preregistration of ten Broeke et al.,).

Convergence / singularity issues.
When running the shared frailty cox regression model gives convergence or singularity problems, we walk through the following steps until the problem will be solved:
1.	Rerun the model while disabling the ‘sparse’ method for estimating the correlation matrix. 
2.	Rerun the model with standardized predictors
3.	Simplify the model following recommendations by Barr, Levy, Scheepers, and Tily (2013)

sample.value:
In total, the worksites have 118 working adults. In order to gain the most precise information as possible from the exploratory analyses in this study, we aim to collect as much data as possible within the limits of the organisation and the study period.

Given the richness of data on the within-participant predictors, and based on similar previous research (ten Broeke et al., manuscript in preparation), we anticipate adequate power to detect small effects for the within-participant predictors. For the between-participant predictors, we conducted an a-priori sensitivity analysis to get an idea of the magnitude of the effect sizes we can detect with adequate power (.80). Specifically, we ran a power simulation in R, using the paramtest package. Using information from our previous research (ten Broeke et al., manuscript in preparation), we ran power simulations for a set of different effect sizes, to determine the magnitude of the HR’s (for a 1 standard deviation increase in any between-participant predictors) we can detect with a power of .80.

The simulation indicated that, given an anticipated participation rate of 85% (n ~100), we can detect HR’s of approximately 1.44 and higher for positive associations with the hazard to stand up or the hazard to sit down, or 0.72 and lower for negative associations, which can be considered medium effects (Azuero, 2016).

analyses.value:
We perform all analyses in R / R studio, using the survival package (Therneau, 2015). We split the complete data into two datasets for separate analyses on the two dependent variables, i.e., the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing: 
•	data_sit.to.stand = only includes event times (rows) for sit-to-stand events
•	data_stand.to.sit = only includes events times (rows) for stand-to-sit events
For all research questions, we fit several shared frailty cox models using the coxph function, with the predictor(s) of interest, and a frailty term for participant, as predictors of the hazard to stand up when sitting or the hazard to sit down when standing. We use the ‘efron’ method for handling ties. Unless otherwise specified, for each model, we determine statistical significance of the fixed effects. When statistically significant, we will interpret the hazard ratio (HR; antilog of the raw coefficient) of the fixed predictors. In addition, we will visually examine plotted survival functions separated for relevant levels of the predictor variables.

RQ1) How are characteristics of the office/room design related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing?

First, we fit two shared frailty cox models, one predicting the hazard to stand up when sitting, and one predicting the hazard to sit down when standing, with roomtype (office vs. meeting room vs. canteen) as predictor.

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ roomtype + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ roomtype + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

Next, we conduct the following analysis steps for each roomtype separately: 
1.	We explore the variance on the individual characteristics, using graphs (e.g., boxplots, scatterplots). Based on these explorations, we exclude characteristics with only little variance. We also explore correlations between individual characteristics, using graphs, correlation tables and chi-square tests. Characteristics that correlate highly, we handle by excluding characteristics that are redundant, or merging characteristics into one overarching characteristics. 
2.	We perform exploratory cluster analysis for mixed data types, to cluster the rooms based on their design characteristics. We start out with using Gower distance as distance-metrics, and partitioning around mediods (PAM) as clustering algoritm. Based on silhouette width statistics, descriptive statistics and visualisation of clusters, we will determine a number of clusters that yields a meaningful interpretation of different offices/meeting rooms/canteens with different typical design characteristics. 
3.	Within each roomtype, we will fit two shared frailty cox models with cluster as predictor, to explore the relation between different room designs and sitting patterns.

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ cluster + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ cluster + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

RQ2) How are the following characteristics of workplace spatial lay-out related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and to the hazard to sit down when standing?

For each workplace spatial lay-out predictor, we fit two shared frailty cox models: one predicting the hazard to stand up when sitting, and one predicting the hazard to sit down when standing. We summarise Hazard Ratios (HRs) and confidence intervals for each predictor in a dot-whisker diagram to interpret the results. 

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ spatial-layout-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ spatial-layout-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

outliers.value:
Inclusion criteria
We recruit a sample of desk-based workers from two different worksites (4 different locations) in the Netherlands. Inclusion criteria to participate in the study are:
-	Working at one of the participating worksites
-	Desk-based work
-	Age 18 or older
-	Working at the office location at for at least 16 working hours in total during the measurement week

Data exclusion
•	Physical conditions. In the intake questionnaire, participants are asked whether they currently experiente any medical or physical condition limiting them in sitting and/or standing, or in sitting down and/or standing up. We visually explore and statistically test whether the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing is different in these participants compared to healthy participants. In case of concern, we perform sensitivity analyses by refitting each model excluding participants with a physical condition. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of results, we report on this. 
•	Working hours. We exclude observations that fall outside of participants working hours. For this, we use self-reported working start and end times. We first narrow the work time window with 15 minutes on both start and end, to correct for recall bias, settling into the building, and make sure commuting behavior is not included. Next, we exclude observations that fall in non-working hours. For observations crossing work start and end times, we retain only observations with at least 50% of time inside the (narrowed) worktime window, and we exclude all other crossing observations. Data of participants for whom no worktime data is available are excluded completely.
•	Non-wear and extreme values. We identify sedentary episodes with a duration longer than 8 hours as non-wear (i.e., time period in which the participant did not wear the activPAL monitor) and therefore these are excluded from the analyses (Edwardson et al., 2017). We identify active episodes with a duration longer than 8 hours as technological failure or extreme values, and therefore these are excluded from the analyses. 
•	Day-reconstruction data: Time spent in rooms. The day-reconstruction data is used to link the activPAL data to the workplace spatial layout data and the office design characteristics data. For each participant, all sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit transitions that in total (i.e., both starttime and endtime) fall between the self-reported starttime and endtime of the period in a certain room, are linked to the characteristics of that room. 
Assumptions
We test the assumptions of multilevel time-to-event analysis as follows:
•	Distribution of predictors. We visually explore histograms to examine the distribution of predictors. In case of serious concerns we refit the model with a transformation of the predictor variable. We use a transformation on the predictor that sufficiently creates a normal distribution, starting with square root transformation, followed by log transformation, followed by inverse transformation (Tabachnik & Fidell, 2013). In case no transformation is useful, we dichotomize the predictor. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this. 
•	Residuals are examined for each model:
o	Deviance residuals. We examine deviance residuals to detect cases that are not predicted well by the model. We evaluate whether the proportion of residuals > 3 is approximately 0%, the proportion of residuals > 2.5 is approximately 1%, and the proportion of residuals > 2 is approximately 5%. In case of concern, we refit the model excluding cases with a deviance residual > 3. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this.  
o	Schoenfeld residuals. We plot schoenfeld residuals against ranked event times, and we test the correlation between schoenfeld residuals and ranked event times, to test the proportionality assumption. A significant correlation indicates violation of the assumption. If the assumption is violated, we follow recommendations by Singer and Willet (2003), and refit and examine a model including an interaction with time as a predictor, to represent the time varying effect.
o	Score residuals. We plot score residuals against ranked event times to detect influential and high leverage cases. In case high-influential cases are concentrated at specific event times, we refit the model excluding observations with extreme score residuals (as the absolute value of score residuals is not meaningful, we choose the cut-off for extreme values based on visual inspection of the graph). When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this. 

Missing data handling
Pairwise deletion

dependent.value:
Dependent variables and measurement
•	The hazard to stand up when sitting, i.e., the probability of standing up per minute of sitting (precision in seconds)
•	The hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., the probability of sitting down per minute of standing (precision in seconds)

Sitting behaviour is defined as “any waking behaviour characterized by an energy expenditure ≤ 1.5 metabolic equivalents (METs), while in a sitting, reclining or lying posture”. In this study, we distinguish between sitting behaviour and activity, referring to all non-sitting behaviour. Sitting behaviour and activity are assessed using an activPAL3 micro (PAL Technologies Ltd, Glasgow, UK), a device that is worn on the thigh that directly assesses posture using triaxial accelerometry. ActivPALs are known to have a good reliability and validity to measure sitting and activity behaviour (for more information on the activPAL see Edwardson et al., 2017). Placement is standardised to the anterior midline of the upper right thigh, with monitors inserted into a flexible waterproof sleeve and attached using a breathable, hypoallergenic dressing. Participants are asked to wear the monitor 24 hours over an 7-day period and not to remove the monitor. The activPAL measures sitting behaviour and activity with seconds precision, and provides timestamped activity code (sitting/lying down; standing; or stepping) for each transition between postures and each step. For this study, standing and stepping are taken together as active, so the data contains a new row for each sit-active and active-sit transition. 
-	Event times in minutes (precision in seconds) are calculated by subtracting the time of the previous event from the time of the current event, e.g., the time of the previous stand up events is subtracted from the current sit-down event.

Predictor variables and measurement

Workplace spatial layout. 
Workplace spatial layout variables are calculated in the same way as Fisher and colleagues (2018), using floor plans and the Spatial Metric Calculator tool which was developed by the Active Buildings study, funded by the National Institute for Health Research’s School for Public Health Research (NIHR SPHR). Specifically, we calculate:
-	The average distance, in metres, to all kitchens/coffee points on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest kitchen/coffee point
-	The average distance, in metres, to all shared printers/copiers on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest shared printer/copier
-	The average distance, in metres, to all meeting rooms on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest meeting room
-	The average distance, in metres, to all lifts on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest lift
-	The average distance, in metres, to all stairs on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest stairs
-	The average distance, in metres, to all WCs on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest WC
-	The average distance, in metres, to all office destinations on the floor
-	The average distance, in metres, to all nearest office destinations
-	The average distance, in metres, to all offices on the floor
-	Centrality, i.e., the average shortest distance to all other points on the spatial graph in terms of number of turns

Office design. 
Office design characteristics for each office, meeting room, and canteen at the worksites are objectively scored by the primary researcher using a for this study specifically constructed Office Design Checklist (ODC). The ODC has a specific subscale for each roomtype: office, meeting room, and canteen. Each subscale involves a list of characteristics of the indoor design of the room that have to be counted, or scored with yes versus no, or with absent versus present outside arm’s reach versus present within arm’s reach, or on another specific scale. Development of the ODC was based on prior research on office ergononomics and sitting behaviour (Duncan et al., 2015; Löffler et al., 2015) and on observations during worksite visits. 

Secondary predictors
Work characteristics. 
For additional robustness analyses, we will explore general and day-level work characteristics as a potential alternative explanations for the relationships between workplace spatial layout and office design characteristics and sitting patterns. In the intake questionnaire (at the start of the study), we assess the following general work characteristics through self-report, using selected and adapted subscales of the Dutch Questionnaire on the Experience and Evaluation of Work (Vragenlijst Beleving en Beoordeling van de Arbeid; VBBA; van Veldhoven & Meijman, 1994):
-	Job title
-	Work pressure
-	Mental load
-	Job autonomy
-	Possibilities for contact
-	Worktime control
-	Task variation
-	Organization focus on stimulating physical activity during work
-	Organizational focus on reducing sitting behaviour during work
In addition, in the daily day-reconstruction questionnaires, we assess the following day-level work characteristics through self-report, using selected and adapted subscales of the VBBA (van Veldhoven & Meijman, 1994):
-	Day-level work pressure
-	Day-level task variation

Workplace habits. 
For additional secondary analyses, we explore the role of the following workplace habits in sitting patterns at work:
-	Use of drinking cans
-	Use of trays
-	Use of towels
-	Use of cups
-	Use of paper versus digital documents
Workplace habits are assessed through self-report. Each workplace habit is assessed with a single item in the intake questionnaire. 

Temporal dynamics and physical fitness. 
Time of the day and activity in last 5 hours are assessed in the same way as in ten Broeke et al., (manuscript in preparation; see ‘linked registrations’ for the preregistration of ten Broeke et al.,). Age, BMI, and leisure time activity level are assessed through self-report, each with a single item in the intake questionnaire. Age is assessed in years. BMI is calculated from self-reported height (in meters) and weight (in kilogram). To assess leisure time activity level, participants are asked how physically active they are outside of work, on a scale from 0 (not at all physically active) to 10 (extremely physically active).

hypothesis.value:
The primary aim of the present research is to explore the role of environmental design in explaining sitting behaviour patterns at work, specifically, the conditional probability of standing up per minute of sitting (= hazard to stand up when sitting) and the conditional probability of sitting down per minute of standing (= hazard to sit down when standing). This aim consists of the following research questions: 

RQ1) How are characteristics of the office/room design related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing?

RQ2) How are the following characteristics of workplace spatial lay-out related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and to the hazard to sit down when standing?
-	Distance to office destinations (within-participants)
-	Distance to nearest office destinations (within-participants)
-	Distance to offices (within-participants)
-	Closeness (within-participants)

The secondary aim of the present research is to replicate and validate findings from ten Broeke et al., (manuscript in preparation; see ‘linked registrations’ for the preregistration of ten Broeke et al.,) regarding the temporal dynamics of the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., associations with time of day and activity in last 5 hours, as well as associations with age, BMI, and leisure time activity level.

First, we fit two shared frailty cox models, one predicting the hazard to stand up when sitting, and one predicting the hazard to sit down when standing, with roomtype (office vs. meeting room vs. canteen) as predictor.

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ roomtype + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ roomtype + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

Next, we conduct the following analysis steps for each roomtype separately: 
1.	We explore the variance on the individual characteristics, using graphs (e.g., boxplots, scatterplots). Based on these explorations, we exclude characteristics with only little variance. We also explore correlations between individual characteristics, using graphs, correlation tables and chi-square tests. Characteristics that correlate highly, we handle by excluding characteristics that are redundant, or merging characteristics into one overarching characteristics. 
2.	We perform exploratory cluster analysis for mixed data types, to cluster the rooms based on their design characteristics. We start out with using Gower distance as distance-metrics, and partitioning around mediods (PAM) as clustering algoritm. Based on silhouette width statistics, descriptive statistics and visualisation of clusters, we will determine a number of clusters that yields a meaningful interpretation of different offices/meeting rooms/canteens with different typical design characteristics. 
3.	Within each roomtype, we will fit two shared frailty cox models with cluster as predictor, to explore the relation between different room designs and sitting patterns.

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ cluster + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ cluster + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)

RQ2) How are the following characteristics of workplace spatial lay-out related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and to the hazard to sit down when standing?

For each workplace spatial lay-out predictor, we fit two shared frailty cox models: one predicting the hazard to stand up when sitting, and one predicting the hazard to sit down when standing. We summarise Hazard Ratios (HRs) and confidence intervals for each predictor in a dot-whisker diagram to interpret the results. 

Sit-to-stand
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ spatial-layout-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_sit.to.stand)
Stand-to-sit
coxph(Surv(time.to.event.m, event) ~ spatial-layout-predictor + frailty(ptcpID), data = data_stand.to.sit)
registration_responses.outliers:
Inclusion criteria
We recruit a sample of desk-based workers from two different worksites (4 different locations) in the Netherlands. Inclusion criteria to participate in the study are:
-	Working at one of the participating worksites
-	Desk-based work
-	Age 18 or older
-	Working at the office location at for at least 16 working hours in total during the measurement week

Data exclusion
•	Physical conditions. In the intake questionnaire, participants are asked whether they currently experiente any medical or physical condition limiting them in sitting and/or standing, or in sitting down and/or standing up. We visually explore and statistically test whether the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing is different in these participants compared to healthy participants. In case of concern, we perform sensitivity analyses by refitting each model excluding participants with a physical condition. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of results, we report on this. 
•	Working hours. We exclude observations that fall outside of participants working hours. For this, we use self-reported working start and end times. We first narrow the work time window with 15 minutes on both start and end, to correct for recall bias, settling into the building, and make sure commuting behavior is not included. Next, we exclude observations that fall in non-working hours. For observations crossing work start and end times, we retain only observations with at least 50% of time inside the (narrowed) worktime window, and we exclude all other crossing observations. Data of participants for whom no worktime data is available are excluded completely.
•	Non-wear and extreme values. We identify sedentary episodes with a duration longer than 8 hours as non-wear (i.e., time period in which the participant did not wear the activPAL monitor) and therefore these are excluded from the analyses (Edwardson et al., 2017). We identify active episodes with a duration longer than 8 hours as technological failure or extreme values, and therefore these are excluded from the analyses. 
•	Day-reconstruction data: Time spent in rooms. The day-reconstruction data is used to link the activPAL data to the workplace spatial layout data and the office design characteristics data. For each participant, all sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit transitions that in total (i.e., both starttime and endtime) fall between the self-reported starttime and endtime of the period in a certain room, are linked to the characteristics of that room. 
Assumptions
We test the assumptions of multilevel time-to-event analysis as follows:
•	Distribution of predictors. We visually explore histograms to examine the distribution of predictors. In case of serious concerns we refit the model with a transformation of the predictor variable. We use a transformation on the predictor that sufficiently creates a normal distribution, starting with square root transformation, followed by log transformation, followed by inverse transformation (Tabachnik & Fidell, 2013). In case no transformation is useful, we dichotomize the predictor. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this. 
•	Residuals are examined for each model:
o	Deviance residuals. We examine deviance residuals to detect cases that are not predicted well by the model. We evaluate whether the proportion of residuals > 3 is approximately 0%, the proportion of residuals > 2.5 is approximately 1%, and the proportion of residuals > 2 is approximately 5%. In case of concern, we refit the model excluding cases with a deviance residual > 3. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this.  
o	Schoenfeld residuals. We plot schoenfeld residuals against ranked event times, and we test the correlation between schoenfeld residuals and ranked event times, to test the proportionality assumption. A significant correlation indicates violation of the assumption. If the assumption is violated, we follow recommendations by Singer and Willet (2003), and refit and examine a model including an interaction with time as a predictor, to represent the time varying effect.
o	Score residuals. We plot score residuals against ranked event times to detect influential and high leverage cases. In case high-influential cases are concentrated at specific event times, we refit the model excluding observations with extreme score residuals (as the absolute value of score residuals is not meaningful, we choose the cut-off for extreme values based on visual inspection of the graph). When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we report on this. 

Missing data handling
Pairwise deletion
registration_responses.dependent:
Dependent variables and measurement
•	The hazard to stand up when sitting, i.e., the probability of standing up per minute of sitting (precision in seconds)
•	The hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., the probability of sitting down per minute of standing (precision in seconds)

Sitting behaviour is defined as “any waking behaviour characterized by an energy expenditure ≤ 1.5 metabolic equivalents (METs), while in a sitting, reclining or lying posture”. In this study, we distinguish between sitting behaviour and activity, referring to all non-sitting behaviour. Sitting behaviour and activity are assessed using an activPAL3 micro (PAL Technologies Ltd, Glasgow, UK), a device that is worn on the thigh that directly assesses posture using triaxial accelerometry. ActivPALs are known to have a good reliability and validity to measure sitting and activity behaviour (for more information on the activPAL see Edwardson et al., 2017). Placement is standardised to the anterior midline of the upper right thigh, with monitors inserted into a flexible waterproof sleeve and attached using a breathable, hypoallergenic dressing. Participants are asked to wear the monitor 24 hours over an 7-day period and not to remove the monitor. The activPAL measures sitting behaviour and activity with seconds precision, and provides timestamped activity code (sitting/lying down; standing; or stepping) for each transition between postures and each step. For this study, standing and stepping are taken together as active, so the data contains a new row for each sit-active and active-sit transition. 
-	Event times in minutes (precision in seconds) are calculated by subtracting the time of the previous event from the time of the current event, e.g., the time of the previous stand up events is subtracted from the current sit-down event.

Predictor variables and measurement

Workplace spatial layout. 
Workplace spatial layout variables are calculated in the same way as Fisher and colleagues (2018), using floor plans and the Spatial Metric Calculator tool which was developed by the Active Buildings study, funded by the National Institute for Health Research’s School for Public Health Research (NIHR SPHR). Specifically, we calculate:
-	The average distance, in metres, to all kitchens/coffee points on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest kitchen/coffee point
-	The average distance, in metres, to all shared printers/copiers on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest shared printer/copier
-	The average distance, in metres, to all meeting rooms on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest meeting room
-	The average distance, in metres, to all lifts on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest lift
-	The average distance, in metres, to all stairs on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest stairs
-	The average distance, in metres, to all WCs on the floor
-	The distance, in metres, to the nearest WC
-	The average distance, in metres, to all office destinations on the floor
-	The average distance, in metres, to all nearest office destinations
-	The average distance, in metres, to all offices on the floor
-	Centrality, i.e., the average shortest distance to all other points on the spatial graph in terms of number of turns

Office design. 
Office design characteristics for each office, meeting room, and canteen at the worksites are objectively scored by the primary researcher using a for this study specifically constructed Office Design Checklist (ODC). The ODC has a specific subscale for each roomtype: office, meeting room, and canteen. Each subscale involves a list of characteristics of the indoor design of the room that have to be counted, or scored with yes versus no, or with absent versus present outside arm’s reach versus present within arm’s reach, or on another specific scale. Development of the ODC was based on prior research on office ergononomics and sitting behaviour (Duncan et al., 2015; Löffler et al., 2015) and on observations during worksite visits. 

Secondary predictors
Work characteristics. 
For additional robustness analyses, we will explore general and day-level work characteristics as a potential alternative explanations for the relationships between workplace spatial layout and office design characteristics and sitting patterns. In the intake questionnaire (at the start of the study), we assess the following general work characteristics through self-report, using selected and adapted subscales of the Dutch Questionnaire on the Experience and Evaluation of Work (Vragenlijst Beleving en Beoordeling van de Arbeid; VBBA; van Veldhoven & Meijman, 1994):
-	Job title
-	Work pressure
-	Mental load
-	Job autonomy
-	Possibilities for contact
-	Worktime control
-	Task variation
-	Organization focus on stimulating physical activity during work
-	Organizational focus on reducing sitting behaviour during work
In addition, in the daily day-reconstruction questionnaires, we assess the following day-level work characteristics through self-report, using selected and adapted subscales of the VBBA (van Veldhoven & Meijman, 1994):
-	Day-level work pressure
-	Day-level task variation

Workplace habits. 
For additional secondary analyses, we explore the role of the following workplace habits in sitting patterns at work:
-	Use of drinking cans
-	Use of trays
-	Use of towels
-	Use of cups
-	Use of paper versus digital documents
Workplace habits are assessed through self-report. Each workplace habit is assessed with a single item in the intake questionnaire. 

Temporal dynamics and physical fitness. 
Time of the day and activity in last 5 hours are assessed in the same way as in ten Broeke et al., (manuscript in preparation; see ‘linked registrations’ for the preregistration of ten Broeke et al.,). Age, BMI, and leisure time activity level are assessed through self-report, each with a single item in the intake questionnaire. Age is assessed in years. BMI is calculated from self-reported height (in meters) and weight (in kilogram). To assess leisure time activity level, participants are asked how physically active they are outside of work, on a scale from 0 (not at all physically active) to 10 (extremely physically active).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The primary aim of the present research is to explore the role of environmental design in explaining sitting behaviour patterns at work, specifically, the conditional probability of standing up per minute of sitting (= hazard to stand up when sitting) and the conditional probability of sitting down per minute of standing (= hazard to sit down when standing). This aim consists of the following research questions: 

RQ1) How are characteristics of the office/room design related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing?

RQ2) How are the following characteristics of workplace spatial lay-out related to the hazard to stand up when sitting and to the hazard to sit down when standing?
-	Distance to office destinations (within-participants)
-	Distance to nearest office destinations (within-participants)
-	Distance to offices (within-participants)
-	Closeness (within-participants)

The secondary aim of the present research is to replicate and validate findings from ten Broeke et al., (manuscript in preparation; see ‘linked registrations’ for the preregistration of ten Broeke et al.,) regarding the temporal dynamics of the hazard to stand up when sitting and the hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., associations with time of day and activity in last 5 hours, as well as associations with age, BMI, and leisure time activity level.

I will be focusing on the fundamental dichotomy of gender and ethnicity as I investigate preferences for mathematics versus the arts.

attributes.title: Audience Psychology: Movie Preferences based on Heart Rate Variability
attributes.description: Heart rate variability (HRV) is a tool that evaluates human emotions. This study aims to adopt a novel and easily administrable method for assessing audiences’ emotional responses to movies and commercials through the monitoring of HRV. During the viewing of audio-visual materials, similarities in HRV may exist across audiences, indicating the impact of the content regardless of genre, be it comedy or tragedy. Furthermore, with reference to audiences’ HRV responses, it is possible to trace back and filter out more emotionally arousing footage for re-editing audio-visual storytelling materials. Through the enhancement of content presentation, the audience engages better.

q1.value: Audience Psychology: Movie Preferences based on Heart Rate Variability

q2.value: Tsz Yan So, Man Yi Erica Li, Hakwan Lau

q3.value: Heart rate variability (HRV) is a tool that evaluates human emotions. This study aims to adopt a novel and easily administrable method for assessing audiences’ emotional responses to movies and commercials through the monitoring of HRV. During the viewing of audio-visual materials, similarities in HRV may exist across audiences, indicating the impact of the content regardless of genre, be it comedy or tragedy. Furthermore, with reference to audiences’ HRV responses, it is possible to trace back and filter out more emotionally arousing footage for re-editing audio-visual storytelling materials. Through the enhancement of content presentation, the audience engages better.

q4.value: If emotional arousal (derived from previous audience’s HRV) affects movie preferences, then new viewers will be more engaged in “the most HRV aroused cuts” than in “the least HRV arouse cuts” or “random cuts” from video footage. Furthermore, we hypothesize that such preference might be moderated by depression or anxiety indices.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have two within-subject designs with 1 factor (emotional arousal of video cuts) with 2 levels each (most aroused vs. least aroused, and most aroused vs. random). Subjects will watch videos from the two levels and rate their preference. The order of the videos is counterbalanced.

q9.value: One of three movies will be randomly assigned to each subject. The order of the two video cuts will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will be compensated at a rate of US$4/hr.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 50 participants per design and hence 100 participants in total.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a large effect size of .51 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: We manipulated the video cuts (2.5 minutes each) based on heart rate variability measured with a previous audience. The three levels are either the 10 most aroused 15-second cuts (“the most aroused”), the 10 least aroused 15-second cuts (“the least aroused”), and 10 random cuts (“random”). Each subject will receive two treatment levels, either “the most aroused” and “random”, or “the most aroused” and “the least aroused”.

One of the outcome variables will be the self-rated engagement of the two video cuts each participant will watch. We will measure this by asking participants “Which video was more engaging” (with 4 levels of responses -  “1st video definitely”, “1st video slightly”, “2nd video slightly”, and “2nd video definitely”). The participants will also fill in the DASS-21 and QIDS-SR16 questionnaires.
We will group the responses “1st video definitely” and “1st video slightly” into a single response of “prefer 1st video”, and likewise for the 2nd video.
We will use a chi-squared test to analyze our results. A chi-square test of goodness-of-fit will be performed to determine whether the two video cuts are equally preferred.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the chi-squared test suggests that the results are significant.

q22.value: The attention of the participants will be checked through the question “What were both videos about” and participants who fail to answer correctly might be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the entire study and the questionnaires, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that depression and anxiety indices may be related to movie preferences or engagement. Therefore, we will look for relationships between those indices and the outcome measures of video preferences.

attributes.title: Interpretation of disjunction in scrambled object

q1.value: Interpretation of disjunction in scrambled objects

q2.value: Shuki Otani, Kazuko Yatsushiro, Mana Asano, Andreea Nicolae

q3.value:
When adult speakers hear a sentence like "Kai had peas or broccoli last night", they understand that Kai didn't have both peas and broccoli last night. Logically, however, the sentence should be true even when Kai had both peas and broccoli. The missing interpretation is due to what is called a Scalar Implicature. Descriptively speaking, given some expressions that form a scale in the sense of Horn (1972) (such as "and" and "or"), a speaker is expected to use an expression that makes the sentence true in fewer situations, in this case, "and"; the speaker is expected to be as informative as possible. When a speaker uses disjunction, rather than conjunction, the hearer interprets that the speaker did not know whether the sentence with conjunction was true or not (Kai had peas and broccoli), hence, interprets it as "Kai had peas or broccoli, but not both."

It has been observed, however, that children interpret sentences with disjunction differently from adults. Singh et al. (2016) reports that the English speaking children that they tested accepted the use of disjunction when both disjuncts were true while rejecting its use when only one of the disjuncts was true. Tieu et al. (2017) report similar results from French and Japanese 4- to 5-year-old children. These authors argue that this behavior can be explained by assuming that children do not know that conjunction and disjunction form a scale, and as a result, their interpretation of disjunction resembles that of conjunction (conjunctive interpretation rather than exclusive interpretation).

More recently, some studies show that changes in experimental material and or condition lead to slightly different results. Skordos et al. (2018) observe that, while Tieu et al.'s result was replicated when they used an identical design, when the condition included an additional object in the scene (three, rather than two potential objects), children started accepting the use of disjunction also in the condition when only one of the disjuncts was true. If this is the case, whether the explanation that Singh et al. propose can be maintained or not remains a question; namely, that children do not have conjunction as an alternative to disjunction, and as a result, an obligatory strengthening mechanism leads them to comprehend disjunction as a conjunction.

Inspired by a study by Shimada (2014), which observes that disjunction in subject and object positions is interpreted differently by both children and adults, Otani et al. (in preparation) tested disjunction in the subject position, adapting the design, used in Tieu et al. (2017). The data from the experiment show that, unlike when the disjunction is in the object position as in Tieu et al. (2017), fewer Japanese speaking children interpreted the disjunction conjunctively. That is, the interpretation of disjunction seems to differ depending on whether it is in the subject position or in the object position. 

There are at least two differences between the subject and object positions: Case (Nominative vs. Accusative), and structural position. In order to test whether the sentence initial position is somehow privileged, we will test sentences where the disjunction occurs in the object, but crucially the object is displaced to the pre-subject position via scrambling. 

OLD: Tieu et. al. (2017) reported that, in positive sentences, children interpret disjunction in the object position conjunctively. However, Otani et. al. (in progress) investigated children's comprehension of disjunction in subject position in positive sentences and found that a majority of  Japanese children interpreted disjunction exclusively. Here, a question arises  as to how the interpretive difference on disjunction between subject and object positions is derived.  We have two possibilities to explain the interpretive difference, the word order and the case marker. Therefore, in the current study, we will conduct an experiment on the interpretation of disjunction in scrambled objects, which get an accusative case placed in sentence initial position.

question.value:
We base our experiment on the design used in Tieu et al. (2017). 

Participants: 20 to 25 4- and 5-year-old Japanese speaking monolinguals, and 10 adult Japanese speakers as a control group. The participants are tested individually in a quiet room.

Method: We use the truth-value judgment task in the prediction mode, as was the case in Tieu et al. In this task, the participant hears a story, narrated by an experimenter, to set-up the scene, while looking at a tablet computer. After the story is told, a puppet shows up in the screen of the tablet computer, and makes a prediction about what happens next. The participant's task is to say whether the puppet predicted what happens next correctly, after watching what happens next on the tablet.

Material: 4 items where both disjuncts are true (2DT condition), 4 items where only one of the disjuncts is true (1DT condition), and 2 items where neither disjuncts are true (0DT condition) are presented to the participant. We prepare two lists with two different orders, in order to avoid the order of the items to have an effect on the results. For the list 1, the items were ordered in alternating orders for 2DT and 1DT. 0DT items were inserted after two stories each of 2DT and 1DT. Three Fillers were inserted to divide the rest of the items into three groups. For the list 2, the order of the non-filler items were simply reversed. There are three filler items, two of which are unambiguously true, one unambiguously false. Participants are assigned to each list randomly.

All experimental sentences are identical to the ones used in Tieu et al, except that the object is scrambled to the sentence initial position in this experiment.

registration_responses.q1: Interpretation of disjunction in scrambled objects
registration_responses.q2: Shuki Otani, Kazuko Yatsushiro, Mana Asano, Andreea Nicolae
registration_responses.q3:
When adult speakers hear a sentence like "Kai had peas or broccoli last night", they understand that Kai didn't have both peas and broccoli last night. Logically, however, the sentence should be true even when Kai had both peas and broccoli. The missing interpretation is due to what is called a Scalar Implicature. Descriptively speaking, given some expressions that form a scale in the sense of Horn (1972) (such as "and" and "or"), a speaker is expected to use an expression that makes the sentence true in fewer situations, in this case, "and"; the speaker is expected to be as informative as possible. When a speaker uses disjunction, rather than conjunction, the hearer interprets that the speaker did not know whether the sentence with conjunction was true or not (Kai had peas and broccoli), hence, interprets it as "Kai had peas or broccoli, but not both."

It has been observed, however, that children interpret sentences with disjunction differently from adults. Singh et al. (2016) reports that the English speaking children that they tested accepted the use of disjunction when both disjuncts were true while rejecting its use when only one of the disjuncts was true. Tieu et al. (2017) report similar results from French and Japanese 4- to 5-year-old children. These authors argue that this behavior can be explained by assuming that children do not know that conjunction and disjunction form a scale, and as a result, their interpretation of disjunction resembles that of conjunction (conjunctive interpretation rather than exclusive interpretation).

More recently, some studies show that changes in experimental material and or condition lead to slightly different results. Skordos et al. (2018) observe that, while Tieu et al.'s result was replicated when they used an identical design, when the condition included an additional object in the scene (three, rather than two potential objects), children started accepting the use of disjunction also in the condition when only one of the disjuncts was true. If this is the case, whether the explanation that Singh et al. propose can be maintained or not remains a question; namely, that children do not have conjunction as an alternative to disjunction, and as a result, an obligatory strengthening mechanism leads them to comprehend disjunction as a conjunction.

Inspired by a study by Shimada (2014), which observes that disjunction in subject and object positions is interpreted differently by both children and adults, Otani et al. (in preparation) tested disjunction in the subject position, adapting the design, used in Tieu et al. (2017). The data from the experiment show that, unlike when the disjunction is in the object position as in Tieu et al. (2017), fewer Japanese speaking children interpreted the disjunction conjunctively. That is, the interpretation of disjunction seems to differ depending on whether it is in the subject position or in the object position. 

There are at least two differences between the subject and object positions: Case (Nominative vs. Accusative), and structural position. In order to test whether the sentence initial position is somehow privileged, we will test sentences where the disjunction occurs in the object, but crucially the object is displaced to the pre-subject position via scrambling. 

OLD: Tieu et. al. (2017) reported that, in positive sentences, children interpret disjunction in the object position conjunctively. However, Otani et. al. (in progress) investigated children's comprehension of disjunction in subject position in positive sentences and found that a majority of  Japanese children interpreted disjunction exclusively. Here, a question arises  as to how the interpretive difference on disjunction between subject and object positions is derived.  We have two possibilities to explain the interpretive difference, the word order and the case marker. Therefore, in the current study, we will conduct an experiment on the interpretation of disjunction in scrambled objects, which get an accusative case placed in sentence initial position.

•	We will explore amplification's effects on perceptions of civility, psychological safety, impact, and willingness to join the group.
•	We will also explore whether psychological safety and impact mediate the relationships between amplification and willingness to voice and amplification and willingness to join the group.  
•	Gender, age, ethnicity, and race are collected as demographics and are exploratory.

sample.value: We will request 230 participants from Amazon's mechanical turk, 115 per condition. After excluding participants (see above) we may have slightly less than 115 per cell.

analyses.value: We will use an analysis of variance with condition as the factor and willingness to voice as the dependent variable.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants with duplicate IP addresses or worker IDs and those that fail the comprehension check question.

dependent.value:
Intention to voice. We will use the question stem "Imagine you work with this same group of people in a real organization. These group members are your full time coworkers. Rate how likely you would be to:" and 6 items to measure willingness to voice (1=Very unlikely, 7=Very likely): Develop and make recommendations to the group concerning issues that affect the organization; Speak up and encourage group members to get involved in issues that affect the organization; Communicate your opinions about work issues to group members even if your opinion is different and others disagree with you; Keep well informed about issues where your opinion might be useful; Get involved in issues that affect the quality of work life in the organization; Speak up with ideas for new projects or changes in procedures

Exploratory measures
Civility: 3 items will measure perceptions of civility: Members of the group expressed continual disapproval of ideas, Members of the group showed enthusiasm for the conversation, and Members of the group helped and encouraged other members (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree.)

Impact/Effectiveness:  3 items will measure perceived impact/effectiveness: If you were a member of this group, what kind of impact do you think you would have on what happens in the group? (1= Very little impact, 7=Very large impact), How much control do you think you would have over what happens in the group? (1=Very little control, 7 = A great deal of control), and How much influence do you think you would have over what happens in the group? (1=Very little influence, 7 = A great deal of influence). 

Psychological Safety. The following 7 items are used to measure psychological safety (1=Definitely no, 5=Definitely yes): In this group, people valued new ideas, In this group, group members were open to alternative ways of getting work done, In this group, people frequently identified and discussed underlying assumptions that might affect key decisions, If you were a member of this group, you would be eager to share information even if it was inconsistent with the group's consensus, The group members engaged in productive conflict and debate during discussions, Differences in opinion were welcomed in this group, and If you made a mistake in this group, people would hold it against you.

Willingness to join group. We will use the following two items (1=Not interested at all, 5 = Very interested): How interested would you be in working in a group like this one? and How interested would you be in joining this group?

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to either the amplification or the control condition. We are using two different scripts for each condition but do not expect differences between the experimental stimuli so we will collapse within conditions.

hypothesis.value: Can amplification in a group increase an observer's willingness to voice in a group with uncivil interactions?

attributes.title: Agreeableness Accounts for the Factor Structure of the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale-III

q1.value: Agreeableness Accounts for the Factor Structure of the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale-III

q3.value:
The purpose of this study is to explain the factor structure of the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale-III (SRP-III) using the Five Factor Model (FFM). Specifically, we will decompose the SRP-III subscales into the FFM facets and determine if these facets, particularly the facets of agreeableness, can explain the structure of the SRP-III (i.e., account for the interrelations among the SRP scales). 

The Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (SRP-III; Williams, Paulhus, & Hare, 2007) is a 64-item self-report assessment of psychopathy developed out of the conceptualization of psychopathy operationalized by the Psychopathy Checklist-Revised (PCL-R; Hare, 2003). The SRP-III has a hierarchical structure composed of four subscales; Interpersonal Manipulation, Callous Affect, Erratic Lifestyle, and Antisocial Behavior, which have been referred to as four factors (Neal &  Sellbom, 2012)

Psychopathy can be conceptualized using the Five Factor Model (FFM) of personality, which measures traits of Neuroticism, Extraversion, Openness, Agreeableness, and Conscientiousness (Costa & McCrae, 1992; Lynam & Miller, 2015).

The PCL-R has a similar factor structure as the SRP-III, but has been hiearchicially organized into a two factor model. Factor 1: Interpersonal Manipulation and Callous Affect, Factor 2: Erratic Lifestyle and Antisocial Behavior.  It has been shown with the PCL-R that Factor 1 is mostly a measure of Agreeableness (A) and and Factor 2 is a measure of A and Conscientiousness (C) (Widiger & Lynam, 1998). The factors are highly correlated because they both assess A, but can be separable because Factor 2 also assesses C.

q4.value:
We predict that all four subscales of the SRP-III will be stongly related to A, and may differ from one other on other FFM facets. 

We predict that when controlling for the A facets, the overlap among the SRP-III subscales will be reduced. We predict that the profile similarities will be relatively strong, with A overlapping with at least half of each subscale. 

We predict that the overlap between the Erratic Lifestyle and Antisocial Behavior subscales will be reduced even futher when additionally controlling for the C facets.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional observational.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
I have not had access to the data before preregistration. The data was kept secure by Dr. Donald Lynam and I will only be given access after this study is pre-registered to conduct the analyses included in this pre-registration. We are conducting specified analyses that were not conducted during the original project for which the data was collected. The analytic plan will follow that of Sherman et al. (2014). This data comes from a previously conducted study investigating the trait structure of the Dark Triad (the related constructs of Psychopathy, Narcissism, and Machiavellianism) (Vize et al., in press).
Sherman et al. (2014) used these types of analyses to decomponse the Youth Psychpathic Traits Inventory (YPI) into FFM elements.

question.value: This study will use previously collected data. Participants were recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk) platform. 8 Attention check items were administered. A failure of two or more attention check items resulted in participant’s data being excluded. 3 Re-captcha items were administered. These are easy to answer open-ended questions (e.g., What is 2+4?). Any incorrect answers on these items resulted in the participant’s data being excluded. Two validity scales (Too Good to be True and Infrequency; 8 items each) from the original Elemental Psychopathy Assessment (EPA; Lynam et al., 2011) were administered to participants. Example items include “I have never in my life been angry at another person” and “I try to eat something almost every day.” Participants’ data was considered invalid if their responses for either scale are 2.75 standard deviations above the sample average. The estimated amount of time to complete the protocol was approximately 20-40 minutes. Thus, completion times faster than 10 minutes resulted in that data not being included in analyses.

q13.value: The original study planned to recruit 1400 participants from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) platform. After the initial posting of the Human Intelligence Task (HIT), a total of 230 participants’ work was rejected based on our exclusion criteria (i.e., completion time, attention checks, and re-captcha items). The study was made available again, and 22 out of the 230 participants’ work was rejected based on our exclusion criteria resulting in N=1,378. Participant data were then inspected for invalid responding using preregistered cutoff scores on the Infrequency and Too Good to Be True validity scales of the Elemental Psychopathy Assessment (EPA; Lynam et al., 2013). An additional 123 participants were excluded resulting in a final sample of N=1,255. This sample will be split randomly in half for the purposes of our analyses.

q14.value: This is based on previously collected data. Justification for this sample size is based on the minimum number of subjects required to stabilize a correlation (250). The sample was randomly split into two samples (Sample 1 N = 627 Sample 2 N = 628) so all analyses can be replicated.

question.value: N/A

SRP-III: 64-item self-report assessment of psychopathy (Williams, Paulhus, & Hare, 2007).

International Personality Item Pool-NEO-120 (IPIP-NEO_120): A freely available, 120-item self-report measure assessing the five domains of the Five Factor Model of personality.

The SRP-III Scaled scores will be calculated based on the scale's four subscales: Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, and Antisocial Behavior. Raw scores from the IPIP NEO will be combined into the 30 facets of the Five Factor Model.

1.	Conduct intercorrelations of the four subscales (Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, Antisocial Behavior) to see how much they relate to each other, and if they are really measuring different components of psychopathy.
2.	We will correlate the 30 IPIP NEO facets with the SRP total,Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, and Antisocial Behavior scores to generate FFM profiles for each.
3.	Calculate similarity scores among the FFM profiles of the SRP total, and Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, Antisocial Behavior subcales using double entry correlations.
4..	We will use a hieararchical regression with four steps. For each pair of SRP subscales, we will first regress one subscale (e.g., IPM) onto the other member of the pair (e.g., Callous Affect), The semi-partial correlation squared gives the overlap between the two subscales.  At step 2, the six Agreeableness facets will be entered and semi-partial correlation squared for the SRP subscale will be compared to the sr-squared from step one. Specifically, dividing the sr-squared from step 2 by the sr-squared at step 1 will reveal what percent of the overlap remains after controlling for the A facets. At step 3, the six Conscientiousness facets will be entered. The sr-squared for the SRP subscale from this step will be compared to the sr-squared from step 2. This comparison will allow us to determine whether the C facets accounted for any additional overlap. Finally, the remaining 18 FFM facets will be entered at step 4 to see if they account for any additional portion of the overlap between SRP subscales. Again, the sr-squared for the SRP subscale at this step will be compred to the sr-squared from step 3.

q20.value: Some items on the SRP-III and the IPIP-NEO will need to be reverse coded. This will occur before the rest of the analyses.

q21.value: Because our research question is looking at how much agreeableness and conscientiousness make up the factors for the SRP-III, minimally 51% of overlap will be noted as a majority of overlap, but 75% and above would be justifiable in drawing stronger conclusions about how agreeableness and conscientiousness account for the factor structure of the scale.

q23.value: A requirement for participants to be included in the study was completion of all the questions asked. Thus, there was very little missing data, and data that are missing were completely at random, so listwise deletion was used.

registration_responses.q11:
I have not had access to the data before preregistration. The data was kept secure by Dr. Donald Lynam and I will only be given access after this study is pre-registered to conduct the analyses included in this pre-registration. We are conducting specified analyses that were not conducted during the original project for which the data was collected. The analytic plan will follow that of Sherman et al. (2014). This data comes from a previously conducted study investigating the trait structure of the Dark Triad (the related constructs of Psychopathy, Narcissism, and Machiavellianism) (Vize et al., in press).
Sherman et al. (2014) used these types of analyses to decomponse the Youth Psychpathic Traits Inventory (YPI) into FFM elements.
registration_responses.q13: The original study planned to recruit 1400 participants from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) platform. After the initial posting of the Human Intelligence Task (HIT), a total of 230 participants’ work was rejected based on our exclusion criteria (i.e., completion time, attention checks, and re-captcha items). The study was made available again, and 22 out of the 230 participants’ work was rejected based on our exclusion criteria resulting in N=1,378. Participant data were then inspected for invalid responding using preregistered cutoff scores on the Infrequency and Too Good to Be True validity scales of the Elemental Psychopathy Assessment (EPA; Lynam et al., 2013). An additional 123 participants were excluded resulting in a final sample of N=1,255. This sample will be split randomly in half for the purposes of our analyses.
registration_responses.q14: This is based on previously collected data. Justification for this sample size is based on the minimum number of subjects required to stabilize a correlation (250). The sample was randomly split into two samples (Sample 1 N = 627 Sample 2 N = 628) so all analyses can be replicated.
registration_responses.q20: Some items on the SRP-III and the IPIP-NEO will need to be reverse coded. This will occur before the rest of the analyses.
registration_responses.q21: Because our research question is looking at how much agreeableness and conscientiousness make up the factors for the SRP-III, minimally 51% of overlap will be noted as a majority of overlap, but 75% and above would be justifiable in drawing stronger conclusions about how agreeableness and conscientiousness account for the factor structure of the scale.
registration_responses.q23: A requirement for participants to be included in the study was completion of all the questions asked. Thus, there was very little missing data, and data that are missing were completely at random, so listwise deletion was used.
registration_responses.q8.question: Cross-sectional observational.
registration_responses.q12.question: This study will use previously collected data. Participants were recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk) platform. 8 Attention check items were administered. A failure of two or more attention check items resulted in participant’s data being excluded. 3 Re-captcha items were administered. These are easy to answer open-ended questions (e.g., What is 2+4?). Any incorrect answers on these items resulted in the participant’s data being excluded. Two validity scales (Too Good to be True and Infrequency; 8 items each) from the original Elemental Psychopathy Assessment (EPA; Lynam et al., 2011) were administered to participants. Example items include “I have never in my life been angry at another person” and “I try to eat something almost every day.” Participants’ data was considered invalid if their responses for either scale are 2.75 standard deviations above the sample average. The estimated amount of time to complete the protocol was approximately 20-40 minutes. Thus, completion times faster than 10 minutes resulted in that data not being included in analyses.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question:
SRP-III: 64-item self-report assessment of psychopathy (Williams, Paulhus, & Hare, 2007).

International Personality Item Pool-NEO-120 (IPIP-NEO_120): A freely available, 120-item self-report measure assessing the five domains of the Five Factor Model of personality.
registration_responses.q18.question: The SRP-III Scaled scores will be calculated based on the scale's four subscales: Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, and Antisocial Behavior. Raw scores from the IPIP NEO will be combined into the 30 facets of the Five Factor Model.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1.	Conduct intercorrelations of the four subscales (Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, Antisocial Behavior) to see how much they relate to each other, and if they are really measuring different components of psychopathy.
2.	We will correlate the 30 IPIP NEO facets with the SRP total,Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, and Antisocial Behavior scores to generate FFM profiles for each.
3.	Calculate similarity scores among the FFM profiles of the SRP total, and Interpersonal Manipulation, Callousness, Erratic Lifestyle, Antisocial Behavior subcales using double entry correlations.
4..	We will use a hieararchical regression with four steps. For each pair of SRP subscales, we will first regress one subscale (e.g., IPM) onto the other member of the pair (e.g., Callous Affect), The semi-partial correlation squared gives the overlap between the two subscales.  At step 2, the six Agreeableness facets will be entered and semi-partial correlation squared for the SRP subscale will be compared to the sr-squared from step one. Specifically, dividing the sr-squared from step 2 by the sr-squared at step 1 will reveal what percent of the overlap remains after controlling for the A facets. At step 3, the six Conscientiousness facets will be entered. The sr-squared for the SRP subscale from this step will be compared to the sr-squared from step 2. This comparison will allow us to determine whether the C facets accounted for any additional overlap. Finally, the remaining 18 FFM facets will be entered at step 4 to see if they account for any additional portion of the overlap between SRP subscales. Again, the sr-squared for the SRP subscale at this step will be compred to the sr-squared from step 3.

attributes.title: Acupuncture for Recurrent Aphthous Stomatitis：A Systematic Review Protocol
attributes.description:
Introduction Recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) is a distressing symptom experienced by patients. Many methods are used to treat, including pudilan anti-inflammatory oral liquid and doxycycline and laser therapy, but these take a long time to produce positive effects and compliance is low. Previous reviews into acupuncture for RAS has been growing, but a systematic review is not available. Therefore, this protocol was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of acupuncture on RAS, by conducting a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Methods and analysis The following databases will be searched from their inception to 1 February 2020: PubMed, Embase, CINAHL, Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, and Wanfang. The randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in English or Chinese associated with acupuncture for patients with RAS will be included. Eligible study conference abstracts and reference lists of manuscripts will also be searched. The data collection and analysis will be conducted independently by two reviewers. The risk of bias of each study will be conducted by the Cochrane risk of bias tool. The heterogeneity will be measured by the I2 statistic. According to heterogeneity testing, data will be synthesized using a fixed-effects model or a random-effects model. A meta-analysis will be performed using Rev Man V.5.3.5 statistical software for each outcome. Subgroup analysis and sensitivity analysis are planned according to clinical evidence. Mean difference or standardized mean difference for continuous data and risk ratio for dichotomous data will be calculated. 
Ethics and dissemination This protocol will not involve individual patient information and endangering participant rights. The results will be reported in a peer- reviewed journal or disseminated in relevant conferences.

q1.value: Prevalence and risk factors of anxiety and depression among breast cancer patients: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Feng Zhang, Yifeng Shen, Xin Tang, Hao Zhao, Songyi Ding, Da Zhang, Chao Wang

q3.value:
Background: Patients with breast cancer often experience severe psychological distress, especially anxiety and depression, leading to poorer quality of life, shortened survival time and increased mortality. Our aim is to summarize data on the prevalence and risk factors of anxiety and depression in patients with breast cancer.
Methods and analysis: We will search Web of Science, PubMed, Science Direct, EMBASE, Wan Fang Data Knowledge Service Platform, Chinese Biomedical Literature Database (CBM), Chinese Scientific Journal Database (VIP database), China National Knowledge Infrastructure(CNKI) and for studies on the prevalence and risk factors of depression in patients with breast cancer, which should be published from inception to Feb 2020 in English and Chinese. The selection of studies, data extraction, and risk of bias assessment will be done independently by two reviewers. Data synthesis will be carried out using Rev Man V.5.3 software. The heterogeneity will be determined by the I²test. Publication bias will be evaluated by generating a funnel plot and performing the Begg and Egger test. The quality of the systematic review will be assessed using the GRADE criteria.

q4.value: This study will review currently researches to provide effective evidence on the risk factors related to depression, and the results of systematic review and meta-analysis will provide significant help in identifying high-risk groups.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2.1. Inclusion criteria for study selection
2.1.1. Types of studies. 
Observational studies with available data on the prevalence and risk factors associated with anxiety and depression among patients with breast cancer will be considered. Cross-sectional, cohort and case–control studies will be excluded. Case reports, case series, opinion papers, qualitative research, letters to the editor, comments, conference proceedings, policy documents, reviews and meta-analyses, study protocols without baseline data, and animal studies will be also excluded. 
2.1.2. Types of patients. Study populations inclusion criteria will be all patients diagnosed with breast cancer , regardless of demographic age, race, and education status.
2.1.3. Types of outcome measures
(1) Prevalence of anxiety and depression among patients with breast cancer. (2) Risk factors associated with anxiety and depression in patients with breast cancer. (3) The strength of correlation between each risk factor and anxiety and depression.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Retrieval databases include: Web of Science, PubMed, EMBASE, Wan Fang Data Knowledge Service Platform, Chinese Biomedical Literature Database (CBM), Chinese Scientific Journal Database (VIP database), China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI). We will also conduct unpublished academic research data. Databases will be searched from inception to Feb. 2020. The reference lists of review articles will be conducted and the following search terms will be used: breast cancer, breast carcinoma, breast tumor, mammary cancer, mammary adenocarinoma, anxiety, anxious, depression, depressive disorder, et al. And we will use the search strategy provided in table 1 for searching the database. The authors will also search relevant trials from Clinical Trials.gov, Google Scholar and WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform.

q13.value: Types of patients. Study populations inclusion criteria will be all patients diagnosed with breast cancer , regardless of demographic age, race, and education status.

question.value: Rev Man V.5.3 will be used to calculate the OR values and 95% CIs of the reported risk factors for anxiety and depression in breast cancer. When the CI of the OR value is not equal to 1 and p<0.05, it is considered statistically significant. The prevalence estimates reported by the individual studies will be extracted or converted into prevalence percentages, and their respective SEs will be calculated. For the anxiety and depression scores, Standardized Mean Difference (SMD) will be used for analysis. We will use the Freeman-Tukey double arcsine transformation to stabilise the variance of study-specific prevalence. The prevalence of each study will be recalculated to confirm numerators and denominators, and adjustments as necessary.
